conclusion: Solve step-by-step to find the electric field strength based on the given scenario.
Small charged ball has three forces acting on it: tension force along the string, gravitational force acting downward, and Coulomb force due to the electric field acting horizontally.
Since the ball is at rest, the sum of all forces must equal zero in both horizontal and vertical directions.

Resolve forces into components: Tension has horizontal component T·sin(θ) and vertical component T·cos(θ); Gravitational force has only vertical component mg; Electric force has only horizontal component qE.
Write equilibrium equations: T·sin(θ) = qE for horizontal equilibrium and T·cos(θ) = mg for vertical equilibrium.
Solve for the tension T using the vertical equilibrium equation: T = mg/cos(θ).
Substitute the value of T into the horizontal equation and simplify to get mg·tan(θ) = qE.
Solve for the electric field strength E: E = mg·tan(θ)/q.
The electric field strength of the uniform electric field is E = mg·tan(θ)/q.

The expression shows that the electric field strength depends on the mass of the ball, the gravitational acceleration, the angle of displacement, and is inversely proportional to the charge of the ball.
